10 M&A DEALS THAT WOULD JUST MAKE SENSE IN 2025

1. $UBER buys $RIVN -- locks in EV supply & takes control of its autonomy roadmap instead of waiting on $TSLA or OEM scraps.

2. $MSFT buys $OKTA -- folds identity leadership into Azure & makes Active Directory the default login layer for enterprise cloud.

3. $ORCL buys $AI -- slaps real gen AI onto Oracle‚Äôs ERP stack & sells AI-native apps to legacy enterprise. 

4. $DDOG buys $FSLY -- locks in real-time edge control to future-proof observability as AI-native systems begin to bypass traditional monitoring stacks.

5. $AMZN buys $TWLO -- brings cloud comms in-house & gives AWS control over the messaging rails developers already use.

6. $GOOGL buys $GTLB -- expands GCP's vertical AI stack by bringing GitLab‚Äôs platform in-house, giving GCP deeper control over the full AI development lifecycle -- from code to production.

7. Databricks buys $CFLT -- completes the modern data stack by merging real-time streaming with lakehouse AI workflows.

8. $CRM buys $BRZE -- expands Salesforce‚Äôs data-driven marketing with Braze‚Äôs event-based engagement engine & mobile-first personalization stack.

9. $AAPL buys Perplexity -- drops Perplexity‚Äôs RAG engine into Safari, Spotlight, and Siri & finally shows up to the AI search war.

10. $CSCO buys $S -- strengthens Cisco‚Äôs AI security portfolio with SentinelOne‚Äôs autonomous threat detection & XDR capabilities.

CHINA TO DEPLOY 115,000+ $NVDA AI CHIPS ACROSS DOZENS OF DESERT DATA CENTERS
EU SET TO FINALIZE US TRADE DEAL BY AUGUST 1 -- COULD HAPPEN WITHIN DAYS

WHY $TSLA & XAI NEED TO MERGE YESTERDAY

Look, I get why people are skeptical. It‚Äôs easy to scoff at the idea of another Elon moonshot when headlines are dominated by political distractions. But strip away the noise, and what you‚Äôre left with is one of the most strategically sound, high-leverage moves Tesla could make right now: merging xAI‚Äôs frontier models with Tesla‚Äôs real-world autonomy stack.

This isn‚Äôt about slapping a chatbot into a car. It‚Äôs about building a native AI agent that can think and act -- locally, in real time -- trained on the most advanced driving dataset on earth. Tesla‚Äôs data flywheel is very real. Every mile driven, every intervention, every edge case -- all of it flows back into Tesla‚Äôs vertically integrated system, from silicon to sensor to software. And that loop tightens further with Dojo, its in-house supercomputer built specifically for this kind of feedback.

Now layer in xAI -- designed from the ground up to run at the edge: low latency, high efficiency, and tightly aligned with Tesla‚Äôs hardware stack built for the physical world.

Here‚Äôs the truth about the new digital economy: you need to own the data, the deployment surface, the silicon -- and now, the models. That only works if you bring xAI under the same roof. Tesla needs xAI‚Äôs model innovation to unlock human-level cognition on-device. xAI needs Tesla‚Äôs deployment scale to keep learning.

And this isn‚Äôt just about autonomy. It‚Äôs about the future of inference cost -- the economic backbone of real-world AI. Whether it‚Äôs a car, a robot, a drone, or a smart factory, whoever can run high-fidelity models locally, fast, and cheap... wins. Vertical integration isn‚Äôt optional anymore. It‚Äôs the moat.

So yes, I think this merger would be a major win for shareholders -- not just as a narrative reset to offset the political overhang on the stock, but because it structurally aligns Tesla to build the first full-stack AI operating system for the physical world.

And in my view, this move is inevitable.

üßµ Why has The Free Markets ETF ( $FMKT ) invested in Uber ( $UBER )? How can Uber benefit from deregulation? The connection is fascinating and potentially profitable for investors. Let‚Äôs dive in‚Ä¶ (1/10)

$FMKT ‚Äôs R2Q system identified Uber as a top regulatory arbitrage opportunity by analyzing key financial metrics alongside potential regulatory impact. My partners and I believe Uber could see significant margin expansion and accelerated growth under the current policy direction. (9/10)

The secret sauce? FMKT‚Äôs proprietary Regulatory Relief Quotient (R2Q) AI system. This tech analyzes regulatory impact + financial metrics to identify companies most likely to benefit from policy shifts. (3/10)

Small-caps look explosive.

Am I wrong?

$FMKT isn‚Äôt your typical ETF. Launched June 2025, it specifically targets companies poised to benefit from deregulation. With a focused portfolio of 25-50 holdings across healthcare, finance, energy, tech, and transportation, it‚Äôs designed to capitalize on regulatory relief. (2/10)

If you have been having a bad day, week, month, year‚Ä¶ Remember, things don‚Äôt happen to you , they happen for you. God makes no mistakes, embrace your situation and find a way to prevail. Find someone to vent to that is on your level. They may need it more than you. Remember, the situation doesn‚Äôt happen to you, it‚Äôs for you. You were built to prevail, make every second count. #selfhealth #grief #happiness #love

Everybody wants to fit in and be extraordinary.

Fitting in is how you guarantee being average.

Don‚Äôt fit in.

Do you.

Would you believe me if I told you that I could predict the #1 factor that will limit American progress?

Electricians.

Followed closely by welders and HVAC technicians. 

We need more young people joining the trades, NOW.

Vehicle electrification, AI compute, cloud data centers, expanding the energy grid, housing, and re-industrialization - all need a boat load of electricians. 

You need robots for manufacturing, e-commerce, hospitals, or smart cities?  I got you. 

You need co-bots or follow-me robots for routine tasks?  I got you there as well.

Need AI to streamline your business or your life?  Some of the world‚Äôs largest companies are working on that as we speak.

However, I have some tough news for you: a humanoid robot (or any type of robot) is not going to build your house, data center, cell phone tower, or wire up all of the fancy robotic systems I design.  

That work will be done by the trades‚Ä¶ for the rest of your life.

Gen 4 nuclear?  Electricians and welders. 

Housing affordability?  Electricians and HVAC technicians.

Manufacturing plant?  Concrete, steel erection, welding, fire protection, electrical, plumbing, millwright, painting, metrology, and more. 

Drill baby drill?  Rough necks need to work the fields. 

Following the trades shortage closely is engineering.  Not computer programmers or software developers. I mean engineers that design things‚Ä¶ that get built.

The national unemployment rate for licensed electricians, certified HVAC technicians, certified welders, licensed  plumbers, and  professional engineers is about 1.5%.

Simply out, we have no more supply.

If the OBBB delivers the boom to our economy and infrastructure that it promises we are woefully unprepared. 

Young people: join the trades NOW. Love math or problem solving?  Engineering school.

General contractors: sign up a labor minimum from your favorite trades contractors now!

Procurement teams: get your long lead items (transformers, switch gear, equipment, robotics, automation, and steel) locked in ASAP.

Humanoids won‚Äôt solve this. AI won‚Äôt solve this. LinkedIn direct marketing and cold email outreach won‚Äôt solve this. 

AI agents might help‚Ä¶ you be more efficient. 

But America need bodies.  Skilled bodies. 

On top of that, many of our foreign worker friends are going home soon.  The new labor numbers show a net change of 3 million jobs shift between foreign and domestic workers‚Ä¶ in Q2 2025!  Let the numbers keep running at this pace and we‚Äôre in for a rude awakening.

Let the foreign investment in the USA manifest and there will be intense competition for skilled trades. 

Let housing boom with deregulation and wait for the shortages.

Let major infrastructure projects begin and see if there are delays due to labor and equipment availability.

Let manufacturing re-shore and watch as the plant floor and the trade contractors compete for the same people. 

For those on this app that yearn for a resurgent middle class and single income households -  your dream is about to come true.

For the PE bros that rolled up trades contractors. Hey, it‚Äôs better to be lucky than good.  You may just get some exits after all. 

For my @GeorgiaTech brothers and sisters that resisted big consulting and actually became a helluva engineer, time to make to rain.  Thanks for your perseverance.

Finally, this is GREAT for the American worker and American companies.  Wages and profits are set to explode. 

I can‚Äôt wait to watch.  You can count on me to do my part.

Lovingly, 
Your neighborhood professional engineer

The $FMKT - $UBER connection reveals how sophisticated investors are positioning for policy-driven returns. As regulations evolve, companies with strong fundamentals AND regulatory tailwinds may outperform. This investment thesis goes beyond traditional metrics. Few. (10/10)

Market projections support this thesis: The ride-sharing market is expected to grow from $74.9B in 2025 to $287.6B by 2034 (16.1% CAGR). Uber‚Äôs super app strategy, fleet electrification, and expansion into tier-2/3 cities position it to capture this growth. (8/10)

Why Uber specifically benefits: 1) Potential labor classification relief preserving its business model 2) Faster autonomous vehicle approvals via the Waymo partnership (250K+ weekly robotaxi rides) 3) Reduced barriers to market expansion 4) Streamlined delivery regulations. (7/10)

The June 2025 ‚ÄúUnleashing American Drone Dominance‚Äù executive order is particularly relevant. It mandates new rules which potentially could accelerate Uber‚Äôs autonomous delivery ambitions by reducing regulatory hurdles. (6/10)

Trump‚Äôs administration has taken a strong ‚ÄúAmerica First‚Äù stance on the gig economy - opposing restrictive regulations, supporting innovation, and defending US leadership in this space. This political shift creates a favorable environment for companies like Uber. (5/10)

Uber‚Äôs numbers tell a compelling story: 170M monthly users, $11.5B Q1 revenue (+14% YoY), and projected EPS growth of 29.79%. But $FMKT sees beyond current performance to regulatory upside potential. (4/10)

I've been closely observing big breakout stocks like CHEF as "canary in the coal mine" indicators, looking for clues to determine if the market's character was shifting toward a more favorable environment for low risk breakout trading. The key words are LOW RISK. Unfortunately, yesterday provided a definitive answer‚Äîthough not the one we hoped for.

If you are a breakout trader using tight stops - even though the indexes have ripped higher - you have likely experienced a low batting average. 

The frequent occurrence of squats and outright failures continues to dominate as a theme around breakout levels, clearly signaling that conditions remain challenging and volatile around key risk levels.

These failed breakouts reveal persistent overhead supply and insufficient follow-through from institutional buyers, underscoring a risk off market with regard to broad-based participation. Hence, the continued gravitation to "old guard" names.

Like you, I remain an active participant and careful observer, adjusting day by day and ensuring risk management remains my top priority. As far as breakout stocks are concerned, this is NOT yet an Easy Dollar environment. For the most part, we are still fighting for pennies. 

For those who have been willing to allow for a bit more volatility, you are likely experiencing better results. If so, congrats; keep doing what is working for you. 

Let me know in the comments if you agree with this assessment and what you are experiencing during this V recovery..

"August 1993 ‚Äì The Moment the Market Met Minervini"

He was just 28.

No hedge fund.
No fancy suits.
Just a young man with a relentless hunger to decode the market.

That summer, while most were running from gold,
Mark Minervini was running toward it.

The headlines were grim.
Sentiment was cold.
But Mark?
He saw something the world didn‚Äôt.

A bottom forming.
A moment of truth.

He didn‚Äôt just talk about it.
He acted‚Äîloading up on gold stocks with unwavering conviction.

In a matter of months, they doubled.

The Goldilocks economy remains intact ‚Äì not too hot, not too cold ‚Äì keeping the long-term bull market alive. But we've gone from recession fears to optimism with the major indexes reaching all-time highs and sentiment readings approaching excessive bullishness. That shift leaves the markets vulnerable to a pullback. As sentiment cools off and rates remain stable, a pullback should be contained to 4-7% peak to trough and present a buying opportunity. If we should rally from here without a pullback and sentiment gets more bullish, I would use that as an opportunity to sell into strength and nail down profits, particularly on extended names.

The second quarter of 2025 was one for the history books. After a sharp 12.1% correction in the S&P 500, the index staged its fastest-ever recovery from a 15% drop, finishing the quarter up 10.6% ‚Äì its strongest showing since Q4 of 2023. That type of V-shaped recovery demonstrates the underlying strength of this bull market, despite persistent macro uncertainty.

However, President Trump‚Äôs unpredictable trade policies continue to inject volatility into the market. This renewed uncertainty is weighing on consumer confidence, business investment, and overall risk appetite. As a result, money managers have gravitated toward mega-cap ‚Äúold guard‚Äù names while small and mid-cap stocks remain significant underperformers.

Cyclical growth sectors have led since the April bottom, with market breadth notably improving into early May. If the Fed delivers a rate cut in September, and tax cuts materialize as expected, cyclical leadership could extend further. Combined with seasonal patterns and typical post-election tailwinds, the setup supports cyclical outperformance through year-end.

Meanwhile, commodities saw turbulent action in Q2, driven by an escalating trade war and U.S. military action against a major OPEC producer. Despite these shocks, the S&P Goldman Sachs Commodity Index (GSCI) ended the quarter down just -4.4%. Precious metals gained 5%, livestock rose 8%, and those moves helped cushion the 9% decline in energy ‚Äì the index‚Äôs largest component.

In the short term, the popular indexes are extended. Sentiment has flipped sharply from ultra-bearish to very bullish, which is a negative from a contrarian standpoint. However, with oil prices retreating and rates remaining stable, the Goldilocks economy appears undisturbed for now. That suggests this bull market remains sustainable. I expect pullbacks to be contained to the 4-7% range and to provide buyable opportunities for disciplined traders.

As always, my focus remains on strong relative strength names, tight volatility contraction setups, and stocks breaking out of proper bases with clear volume confirmation. Remember, in bull markets, the key is not to fight the tape but to execute with precision and strict risk control.

Stay disciplined and stay alert ‚Äì opportunity always emerges for those prepared.
